messages.subject: Re: Kogai Naoshi
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you very much Gordon.  I can see a very fine line at the blade insertion end which resembles what you describe.  It makes sense. Thanks again and take
messages.messageBody:
Thank you very much Gordon. I can see a very fine line at the blade
insertion end which resembles what you describe. It makes sense.
Thanks again and take care.
Pete

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kogai Naoshi
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Pete, The plate with the design and nanako is cut out of the kogai and that plate is fitted into the top plate of a kozuka. Usually you can see a change in
messages.messageBody:
Hi Pete,

The plate with the design and nanako is cut out of the kogai and that
plate is fitted into the top plate of a kozuka. Usually you can see a
change in the nanako or even a line where the kogai plate has been
inserted into a kozuka plate.

Gordon

On 2005/11/25, at 10:07, klepet33319 wrote:

> Good day to all and a Happy Thanksgiving to whom it will apply! Does
> anyone know of the process by which kogai were reformed to kozuka? I
> have recently received a kozuka naoshi and I notice it has the same
> triangular taper of standard kozuka and as I believe kogai are flat I
> am wondering how it was re-constructed? Thanks much!
> Pete Klein

messages.subject: Kogai Naoshi
messages.msgSnippet: Good day to all and a Happy Thanksgiving to whom it will apply!  Does anyone know of the process by which kogai were reformed to kozuka?  I have recently
messages.messageBody:
Good day to all and a Happy Thanksgiving to whom it will apply! Does
anyone know of the process by which kogai were reformed to kozuka? I
have recently received a kozuka naoshi and I notice it has the same
triangular taper of standard kozuka and as I believe kogai are flat I
am wondering how it was re-constructed? Thanks much!
Pete Klein
